III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction, prevention; prohibited
Title restraints; elimination of restraints
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159
Section (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
Description manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity
of the youth's behavior, chronological and developmental age,
size, gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth's
treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 10/18/2024, Youth A became upset and started walking off the
campus because he was told "no." Therapist 2 and Staff 2 were
able to catch up with Youth A. Staff 2 walked in the street and
Therapist 2 was 10 feet behind him as he walked on the side of
Youth A who was walking on the sidewalk. During this time,
Therapist 2 called Staff 1 and Therapist 1 to come and assist. At
some point, Youth A made movement towards oncoming traffic,
so Staff 2 placed Youth A into a one person hold. Seconds later
Therapist 2 stepped in to assist making it a two person hold. The
two-person hold took place for a minute and a half. Youth A
dropped his weight and Youth A was released from the 2- person
hold. Youth A then sat on the ground. Once on the ground, Youth
A attempted to run into the street again, so Therapist 2 and Staff 2
placed Youth A back into a two person hold. Seconds later,
Therapist 1 and Staff 1 arrived. Therapist 2 switched positions
with Therapist 1 and contacted the unit nurse. Therapist 1 and
Staff 2 held Youth A from 4:45 PM to 4:59 PM. By that time, Youth
A was willing to walk back to the facility with an open hand escort.
Once released to the unit, Youth A attempted to attack Therapist 1
and was placed in a one person hold by Staff 2 for an unknown
length of time. Once Youth A was released, he began charging at
Staff 2, so Staff 1 placed Youth A in a one person hold and then
released Youth A. Ten minutes later, Youth A repeatedly kicked
the table on the side and began pushing the table with his foot.
Youth A's foot lost control causing him to hit his collar bone on the
table. Youth A sustained a mark on his collar bone. Youth A also
has marks on his left and right forearm and biceps due to the one
and two man holds.
2

Investigation Administrator 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
10/21/2024. Administrator 1 was not witness to the incident but
reported being aware of the allegations.
Youth A was observed interacting with a staff at the facility
on 10/21/2024. The interactions were appropriate, and Youth A
appeared to be doing well. Youth A was interviewed via phone
on 10/24/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A
reported being at the facility for approximately 2 to 3 months and
stated, “things are going great”. Youth A reported staff are friendly
and nice towards him and Youth A “would not change a thing”.
Youth A identified Therapist 1 as Youth A’s primary therapist who
is very helpful. Youth A reported being restrained last Friday
(10/18/24) after becoming angry when staff (unable to identify)
said something about Youth A’s family. Youth A reported Youth A
was running and staff caught up to Youth A and “grabbed” Youth
A from behind. Youth A reported Youth A was walking towards the
road when a staff who he could not recall who “grabbed” Youth
A’s arm and pulled Youth A away from the road and towards
another staff. Youth A reported being in a standing hold with two
staff whom he did not recall, on either side of Youth A for
approximately 20 to 30 minutes. Youth A reported Youth A was
not trying to hurt anyone but was just trying to get to the road, so
Youth A could walk to the library off campus. Youth A reported this
is the first time Youth A has experienced a restraint at the facility
and Youth A has been doing well since the restraint. After the
restraint, Youth A reported not being checked by a nurse.
Therapist 2 was interviewed via phone on 10/24/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported being present
during the incident and restraint. She reported first being made
aware of Youth A becoming dysregulated when Staff 3 texted
Therapist 2. Therapist 2 advised Staff 3 to have Staff 3 and Youth
A begin walking back to the building from the basketball court.
Therapist 2 reported Youth A and Staff 3 just got to the building
when Staff 3 swapped out with Staff 2 and began supervising
Youth A. Therapist 2 believed this would help Youth A since Staff
2 has a good relationship with Youth A but within a few minutes
she received a call for help from Staff 2. Staff 2 reported to
Therapist 2 that Youth A was leaving campus and walking towards
the road. Therapist 2 reported getting other staff to cover her
supervision of other youth and going outside to find Youth A
walking towards the road with Staff 2 about 3 to 4 feet behind
Youth A. Therapist 2 reported staying about 10 to 15 feet away, so
she didn’t escalate Youth A anymore than Youth A already was.
Therapist 2 reported calling Staff 1 (Emergency Care Supervisor)
3

and Therapist 1 for help. Youth A began to run towards the road at
which time, Staff 2 placed Youth A in a single person standing
hold and Therapist 2 ran up and assisted, placing Youth A in a
standing 2-person hold. Therapist 2 reported Youth A sat down so
Therapist 2 and Staff 2 let go of Youth A who sat for a moment
and then tried to run towards the road again. Therapist 2 and Staff
2 then placed Youth A in a 2-person standing hold again.
Therapist 2 reported explaining to Youth A that the restraint was
used because Youth A was running towards the road. Staff 1 and
Therapist 1 approached the scene and Therapist 1 swapped with
Therapist 2. Therapist 2 reported calling nursing department at
this time because that is the facility policy. Youth A was still
refusing to go back to the building (unit) but in a few minutes,
Therapist 1 and Staff 2 convinced Youth A to begin walking back
towards the building. Therapist 1 and Staff 2 released their hold
on Youth A because Youth A had begun to willingly walk back.
Once Youth A, Therapist 1, Therapist 2, Staff 1, and Staff 2
entered the milieu of the unit, Youth A began punching and hitting
Therapist 1. Therapist 2 reported Staff 2 placed Youth A in a 1-
person standing hold and Therapist 1, and Therapist 2 left the
milieu. Staff 2 released the hold and planned to step away, but
Youth A began to hit Staff 2. Staff 1 then intervened and placed
Youth A in another standing 1-person hold. Staff 2 was able to get
out of the milieu and finally Staff 1 let go and got into a hallway
away from Youth A. While in the milieu, Youth A flipped a table
and struck Youth A’s collar bone on the edge of the table. Youth A
stayed in the milieu for a few minutes more before calming down
at which time Youth A went to Youth A’s room and took a nap.
Regarding the restraints, Therapist 2 reported these actions were
taken appropriately and all staff followed facility behavior
management policy.
Therapist 1 was interviewed via phone on 10/24/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported being the
primary therapist for Youth A and got involved after receiving a
call from Therapist 2 about the situation near the road. Therapist 1
reported Youth A was in a standing 2-person hold near the road.
Therapist 1 reported giving Youth A options and as Youth A
become more responsive, Youth A choose to begin walking
towards the building. Once Youth A was walking, Therapist 1
engaged in a technique which is an open-handed escort.
Therapist 1 reported once back in the milieu and removing the
escort, Youth A got physical with Therapist 1. Therapist 1 “tried to
get out of there” before Staff 2 engaged in a 1-person hold. This
allowed Therapist 1 to get to safety and once Staff 2 released
Youth A, Youth A began to attack Staff 2. Staff1 engaged in a 1-
4

person hold allowing Staff 2 to get to safety. Therapist 1 reported
noticing marks on Youth A’s arm and admitted they were holding
Youth A tight to keep him from struggling or break away again.
Therapist 1 reported the restraints were according to policy and he
had no concerns about staff’s actions.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 10/24/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported becoming
involved when receiving a call from Therapist 2. He reported when
reaching the scene, he observed Youth A running towards Shaffer
Road and when reaching them, Staff 2 and Therapist 1 had Youth
A in a 2-person standing hold. Staff 1 reported Youth A was
threatening and resisting the hold while Therapist 1 was trying to
deescalate Youth A. Staff 1 reported Youth A calmed down
enough to be escorted to the building. Staff 1 reported once back
in the building, Youth A began hitting Therapist 1 before Staff 2
placed Youth A in another 1-person standing hold. Once Staff 2
released Youth A, Youth A began attacking Staff 2 at which time
Staff 1 placed Youth A in a 1-person standing hold. Staff 1
reported once releasing Youth A, Staff 1 was quick enough to get
behind a hallway door leaving Youth A alone in the milieu. The
milieu space is very large and there are several windows in which
the staff involved were observing Youth A throughout the entire
time. The milieu is a locked room as are all the rooms in the
facility since it is a secure facility. At no time did Youth A present
as trying to get out of the room. A BCBA staff spoke to Youth A
and helped calm Youth A down even more. Staff 1 reported being
told by Therapist 1 that bruising was observed on Youth A’s bicep,
and this would need to be called into Central Intake. Staff 1
reported the restraints were appropriate and done per policy.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 10/24/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 2 reported being in the
process of making dinner when he received a text that Youth A
was refusing to reenter the building. Staff 2 reported swapping out
with Staff 3 to provide supervision for Youth A. Staff 2 reported
Youth A informed him Youth A was mad at Staff 3 but provided no
details. Staff 2 reported Youth A kept refusing to enter the building
and began to walk in the “wrong” direction. Staff 2 reported
walking behind Youth A and calling for support because Staff 2
observed behaviors from Youth A suggesting Youth A was getting
ready to run away. Staff 2 reported Therapist 2 came to support
but stayed well behind both Youth A and Staff 2. Staff 2 reported
walking to the side of Youth A and staying between the sidewalk
and the road. As Youth A made a move towards the road, Staff 2
reported Therapist 2 told Staff 2 to restrain Youth A to keep Youth
5

A from going into the road. After engaging in a 1-person standing
hold Therapist 2 helped and made it a 2-person hold. Youth A
went to the ground and Staff 2 and Therapist 2 let go of Youth A
as Youth A sat on the ground. Staff 2 reported Youth A was
threatening both Staff 2 and Therapist 2 before trying to get to the
road again. Therapist 2 and Staff 2 both engaged in a 2-person
hold as Therapist 1 showed up and swapped out with Therapist 2.
Staff 2 reported escorting Youth A with Therapist 1 back to the
unit since Youth A had calmed down and stopped resisting. Once
back in the building, staff moved away from Youth A, Youth A
began to attack Therapist 1. Staff 2 placed Youth A in a 1-person
hold. Once releasing Youth A from this hold, Youth A began to
attack Staff 2 so, Staff 1 placed Youth A in another 1-person hold.
Staff 2 reported all staff were able to get to safety while still
providing supervision to Youth A. Staff 2 reported not observing
any bruising on Youth A and believed the restraints were all
conducted appropriately and per policy.
Youth B was interviewed via phone on 10/24/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth B reported feeling
safe at the facility and being placed at the facility a couple of
months ago. Youth B reported liking the staff but finding the
overnight staff “mean” but was unable to provide any specific
details of what “mean” looks like. Youth B reported never
witnessing a youth at the facility being restrained.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on 10/24/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 3 reported supervising
Youth A when he was playing basketball. Staff 3 reported Youth A
became upset when not winning a basketball game and began to
throw the basketball at Staff 3 in an aggressive manner before
moving to the far end of the basketball court. Staff 3 walked to the
far end of the court but kept distance from Youth A. Staff 3
reported calling Therapist 2 to inform her of Youth A’s escalation.
Staff 3 reported Youth A asked to walk to the gym and after Staff 3
suggested going into the unit Youth A said Youth A didn’t want to
go into the unit. Staff 3 reported telling Youth A that Youth A could
not stay outside without adult supervision and suggested they
walk back to the unit to take their water bottles inside. While
walking towards the unit, Staff 3 reported calling for help. Staff 2
came out and swapped with Staff 3. Staff 3 reported not
witnessing any of the interactions with Youth A after this time.
Documents Reviewed:
6

Wedgewood Christian Services Significant Event Report
dated 10/18/24 for Youth A. This document outlines Youth A,
Therapist 1, Therapist 2, Staff 1, and Staff 2 as being involved in
this event. The event is classified as youth related behavior
management. The event is document as occurring just as
described by the staff interviewed. It is also documented that
nursing was informed of the event.
Wedgewood Christian Services Behavior Management Report
dated 10/18/24 for Youth A. This document outlines the use of
physical behavior management techniques occurring in this
incident. It is documented Staff 2 was involved in the first restraint
(1 minute), Staff 2 and Therapist 2 were involved in the second
restraint (1 minute), Staff 2 and Therapist 2 were involved in the
third restraint (1 minute), Therapist 1 and Staff 2 were involved in
the escort (6 minutes), Staff 2 was involved in the fourth restraint
(1 minute), and Staff 1 was involved in the sixth restraint (1
minute). It is also documented nursing staff followed-up with
Youth A and “abrasions and bruising on right and left bicep and
forearms”. No medical care was required at this time and nursing
staff will assess injuries on campus on Monday 10/21/24. It is
documented the restraints began due to potential bodily harm if
Youth A comes in contact with traffic. A call to MDHHS is
documented to have occurred. A debriefing and administrative
review is documented as occurring on 10/18/24.
Nursing Note dated 10/18/24 for Youth A. This document
outlines that Nurse 1 was contacted by staff indicating Youth A
was attempting to go AWOL and was restrained near the road. It
is then documented Nurse 1 was contacted informing her that
Youth A was now back on the unit. Nurse 1 was contacted and
informed Youth A suffered an injury (bruise) on Youth A’s collar
bone when flipping over a table and striking Youth A on the collar
bone. The final contact with Nurse 1 was made and Nurse 1 was
informed about bruising and scratches on bilateral upper arms
from the hold.
Nursing Note dated 10/21/24 for Youth A. This document
outlines the assessment by Nurse 2 on Youth A. It is documented
Youth A has a small bruise on upper left anterior chest and
several small bruises over bilat upper arms. Youth A is not
complaining of pain.
August 19, 2024, letter to Case Manager from the facility
regarding Youth A. This letter documents the facility’s request for
1:1 supervision for Youth A involving seven days a week and 12-
7

hours per day. The facility documents Youth A’s behaviors issues
as elopement, AWOL, concealing a knife, fire-setting, physical
aggression, property destruction, and theft as reasons for the
increased supervision. This letter is signed by Therapist 1 and
Administrator.
2023 Suicide Precaution Table. This document outlines different
levels of behaviors regarding possible self-harm and suicidal
behaviors. There are three categories outlined and include “At
Risk, High Risk, and Maximum Risk”. Cross referencing each
category are the categories of “guideline, possible indicators,
action, communication, documentation, and criteria for reducing
precaution”. It is documentation that each staff member must be
familiar with their roles and responsibilities regarding these
possible behaviors by youth.
Wedgwood Crisis Management Procedures 03-17 dated July
3, 2024. This document indicates that physical restraint is to be
used as a last resort when a youth poses an imminent danger to
self or others. The physical restraint is to be used only in
emergency or crisis situations and after less restrictive measures
have proven ineffective. If a restrain does occur a qualified
supervisor must process the event with all staff members who
were involved in the incident before the end of the shift and the
event must be documented on a Behavior Management Report.
Wedgwood Behavior Management Procedures 03-16 dated
July 3, 2024. This document outlines the need for staff to engage
in verbal de-escalation approaches and activation of youth self-
control or sensory plans prior to any physical engagement.
Building healthy and therapeutic relationship with youth is needed
to help the youth develop personal growth and increase self-
control. Staff need to avoid excessively controlling the
environment and allow the youth to make choices and exercise
the responsibility of self-control.
Wedgwood Truancy and missing person Procedures 03-15
dated July 3, 2024. This document outlines the
process/procedures staff are to use when truancy or AWOL
occurs with a youth. Staff are to remain alert to youth moods,
attitudes, and behaviors that may signal the possibility of these
specific behaviors. Staff are to make sure youth do not have
access to the use of any unit keys or staff’s personal keys. If a
youth engages in being truant, staff are to maintain eyes on the
youth and monitor the youth unless the pursuit places the youth or
staff member in danger. Staff are to verbally encourage the youth
8

to return and may engage in a physical restraint if serious harm is
imminent to the youth.
Video recording review. The view of the camera is from the
ceiling with the entrance to the milieu of the unit Youth A is
housed in. Youth A is escorted into the milieu and once released,
Youth A begins to hit Therapist 1. Therapist 1 rushes out of the
room while Staff 2 begins a 1-person standing hold. Staff 2
releases Youth A and begins to walk away while Youth A follows
and begins to punch Staff 2. Staff 1 then begins a 1-person
standing hold so Staff 2 can exit the room. Staff 1 releases the
hold and leaves the camera view. Youth A walks around and tips
over a table in the milieu before sitting on a counter. A few
moments later Youth A is given something to drink by a staff just
out of the camera view.
HR file for Staff 1 who was hired on 9/21/97 had no
documentation of any disciplinary action. Documentation also
indicates Staff 1 is current on his trainings with the last Crisis
Prevention & De-escalation 8-hour training taking place on
7/27/24.
HR file for Therapist 1 who was hired on 9/6/14 had no
documentation of any disciplinary action. Documentation also
indicates Therapist 1 is current on his trainings with the last Crisis
Prevention & De-escalation 4-hour training taking place on
9/11/24.
HR file for Therapist 2 who was hired on 9/19/22 had
documentation of 2 disciplinary actions being taken not related to
restraints. Documentation indicates Therapist 1 is current on his
trainings with the last Crisis Prevention & De-escalation 4-hour
training taking place on 9/11/24.
HR file for Staff 2 who was hired on 4/30/24 had documentation
of 2 disciplinary actions being taken not related to restraints.
Documentation indicates Staff 2 is current on his trainings with the
last Crisis Prevention & De-escalation 4-hour training taking place
on 9/11/24.
Behavior Management Aegis Holds. This document shows what
the 2-person level 1 hold should look like. One staff on each side
of the youth with staff holding the wrist of the side they are on and
the other arm under the arm of the youth holding the youth by the
youth’s upper arm and the staff’s elbow. The other hold displayed
is the 1-person emergency benevolent hold.
9

Analysis The agency is found in compliance as based on interviews with
staff, written documentation, and video recording staff followed the
policies and procedures, for their interactions with Youth A and the
restrains used.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered to review seclusion definition to
ensure staff have clear understanding and actions taken do not
result in a youth being secluded.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
